skill.name: scientific-visualization
skill.description: Create publication figures with matplotlib/seaborn/plotly. Multi-panel layouts, error bars, significance markers, colorblind-safe, export PDF/EPS/TIFF, for journal-ready scientific plots.
skill.summary: Create publication figures with matplotlib/seaborn/plotly. Multi-panel layouts, error bars, signific...
skill.author: davila7

security_audit.summary: This skill consists of Python helper modules for matplotlib visualization configuration. All code performs standard data visualization tasks with no network access, credential handling, or suspicious execution patterns. The scripts only write figure files to user-specified paths.

content.value_statement: Scientists spend hours formatting figures for journal submission. This skill provides pre-configured matplotlib styles, colorblind-friendly palettes, and automated export tools to create professional figures in minutes instead of hours.
actual_capabilities: Apply journal-specific styles (Nature, Science, Cell, IEEE)
Use colorblind-friendly palettes (Okabe-Ito, Wong, Paul Tol)
Create multi-panel figures with GridSpec layouts
Export figures in PDF, EPS, PNG, TIFF formats
Add error bars, significance markers, and statistics
Configure figure dimensions for journal column widths
limitations: Requires matplotlib, seaborn, and plotly packages
Cannot create interactive visualizations for web embedding
Does not perform statistical analysis on data
Font embedding verification requires PyPDF2 package

use_cases.title: Manuscript Figures
use_cases.description: Prepare figures for journal submission with correct format, DPI, and dimensions for Nature, Science, Cell, and other journals.

use_cases.title: Thesis and Presentation Graphics
use_cases.description: Create professional plots for theses and conference presentations with consistent styling and publication quality.

use_cases.title: Scientific Reports
use_cases.description: Generate clear, accessible visualizations for scientific reports that meet publication standards and accessibility requirements.

prompt_templates.title: Basic Line Plot
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a publication-quality line plot with error bars showing treatment effects over time. Use Okabe-Ito color palette. Figure should be 89mm wide for Nature journal single column.

prompt_templates.title: Multi-Panel Figure
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a 2x2 multi-panel figure with panel labels (A, B, C, D). Each panel should have different plot types showing related data. Use consistent styling across all panels.

prompt_templates.title: Statistical Comparison
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a box plot with individual data points overlaid and significance markers comparing three treatment groups to control. Include sample size annotations.

prompt_templates.title: Journal-Specific Export
prompt_templates.prompt: Configure the figure for Nature journal submission. Export as PDF at 600 DPI with proper dimensions. Verify figure size compliance with journal specifications.

output_examples.input: Create a publication-ready bar plot comparing gene expression levels between wild-type and mutant samples with error bars and significance markers.
output: Figure configuration: Single column width (89mm), Arial 7pt font, Okabe-Ito palette
Panel showing: Control (WT) vs Mutant A vs Mutant B bars with error bars (SEM)
Significance markers: *** (p < 0.001) between WT and each mutant
Export formats: PDF (vector, 600 DPI), PNG (300 DPI)
Figure saved as: gene_expression_comparison.pdf and gene_expression_comparison.png

best_practices: Always test figures in grayscale to ensure accessibility and print compatibility
Use vector formats (PDF, EPS) for line art and graphs to maintain quality at any size
Limit color palettes to 7-8 colors maximum per figure for clarity
Verify figure dimensions match target journal specifications before export
anti_patterns: Using JPEG format for scientific figures (compression artifacts distort data)
Relying solely on color to distinguish data series (add line styles and markers)
Using rainbow (jet) colormap which is not perceptually uniform
Truncating bar chart axes away from zero which misrepresents data

faq.question: Which color palette is most colorblind-friendly?
faq.answer: The Okabe-Ito palette is recommended as it is distinguishable by all types of color blindness.

faq.question: What DPI is required for most journals?
faq.answer: Line art requires 600-1200 DPI or vector format, while photographs need 300-600 DPI at final print size.

faq.question: How do I apply Nature journal style?
faq.answer: Use plt.style.use('assets/nature.mplstyle') or import style_presets and call configure_for_journal('nature').

faq.question: Is my data safe when using these scripts?
faq.answer: Yes. Scripts run locally, read only your data arrays, and write only figure files you specify.

faq.question: Why do my figures look different after export?
faq.answer: Vector formats (PDF, EPS) preserve quality at any size. Raster formats (PNG, TIFF) depend on DPI setting.

faq.question: Can I use these tools with seaborn?
faq.answer: Yes. Apply publication styles first, then configure seaborn with sns.set_theme(context='paper', style='ticks').
